Award.AwardTitle: BRIGE: Combining High Speed Extrusion and Nanoscale Interactions for Efficient Processing of Renewable Polyester Nanocomposites

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description:

This BRIGE project will seek routes to improved thermophysical properties for renewable polymers through the formation of nanocomposites. The viability of renewable plastics depends on low-cost processing and expansion of the thermomechanical properties for a broad range of applications. The objective of the research is to understand the effects of novel high-speed extrusion processing of nanocomposites with renewable polymer matrices. Conventional twin screw extrusion reaches rotation speeds of 400 rpm, but next-generation extruders are now available that can achieve 4500 rpm. Extrusion blending at these high speeds has the potential to transform understanding of nanocomposite processing. Application of high shear can also degrade sensitive renewable polymers, so the limits to this technique must be explored. This work will also relate the effects of surface functionalization to rheological and structural properties of the nanocomposites to deduce the mechanisms of interfacial toughening. Theoretical findings relating enthalpic interactions, dispersion and reinforcement are more broadly applicable to other polymer-nanoparticle systems. The intellectual merit of the proposed research will be provided through: (1) potentially transformative capabilities of the new extrusion mixing technology, (2) quantitative understanding of the roles of interfacial interactions and dispersion in nanocomposite polymer reinforcement including a rheological model of processing properties, and (3) foundational knowledge on processing behavior of renewable polymers.

Broader Significance and Importance:

The project will have broader impacts on society through its focus on sustainable materials, education of the next generation of scientists, and broadening participation of women in engineering. The new paradigm for reinforcement of polymers from renewable resources will accelerate their route to commercialization. The improved particle dispersion achieved through high-speed mixing will lead to lighter, stronger and more sustainably manufactured nanocomposites. Knowledge gained on the novel processing technique will be applicable to a range of multicomponent materials. Integration of research and education will be accomplished through a "teach the teachers" pilot program that provides polymers-focused experimental examples for area high school teachers. An important focus of this project is to broaden participation of women in engineering, specifically addressing attrition from college entry to the professional workplace.

Broadening Participation:

The broadening participation objective of this project is to create mentorship networks among women at multiple engineering career and academic levels. Interactive discussions at high school technical programs will establish a supportive mentorship network among female students interested in engineering. The success of the cooperative training program at UMass Lowell will be leveraged for sharing of career experiences among student groups. Participating students will have the opportunity to observe and model success in all stages of the engineering career. The integrated educational and outreach activities with area high schools and vocational programs will provide opportunities in engineering for at-risk students and increase retention among female engineering students at the outset of their careers.

This research has been funded through the Broadening Participation Research Initiation Grants in Engineering solicitation, which is part of the Broadening Participation in Engineering Program of the Engineering Education and Centers Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This BRIGE project studied high-speed twin screw extrusion processing as a means of improving the thermophysical properties of renewable polymers through formation of nanocomposites. Biobased polyester poly(butylene succinate) (PBS) was compounded with a range of surface-functionalized silicas, and the effects of high shear and interfacial energy on the nanocomposite microstructure, rheology and properties were explored. The outcomes of this work were: (1) increased understanding of the ability of a novel, ultra-high speed extruder to disperse nanoscale particles in a polymer matrix, (2) the effects of that dispersion on rheological properties, and (3) increased participation of women in engineering through cooperative education outreach at high schools. The findings of this research project were published in four peer reviewed publications. 

Intellectual merit

This project increased knowledge on rheology and processing for PBS-silica nanocomposites, and demonstrated the effectiveness of two organo-silane grafted silicas vs. hydroxyl-surface silica in reinforcing the polymer. Polymer-particle interaction was varied by grafting two silane coupling agents: short chain methyltrichlorosilane (MTS) and long chain octadecyltrichlorosilane (OTS), onto the silica surface. Rheology data indicated a transition to a solid-like response at low shear rates. The response after a step shear strain indicated that PBS/OTS-modified silica displayed the longest sustained rubbery behavior – in fact terminal relaxation was not observed during the test time (t<100,000s). Therefore, it was concluded that the OTS modification resulted in stronger interactions with the polymer chains.

A diffusion-reptation molecular model was used to determine the fraction of strongly bound polymers in the nanocomposites from their linear viscoelastic response in rheological measurements. The results obtained were in quantitative agreement with the values estimated from the changes in the heat capacity during the glass transition. It was found that the amount of confined polymer depended on both particle fraction and polymer-particle interfacial interactions. Specifically, the bound layer fraction increased with higher particle loading, and it also increased with greater polymer-particle compatibility.  

A self-assembled structure of the PBS/fumed silica system was achieved using steady shear flow. The structural reorganization was demonstrated as an overshoot in the stress growth in a stress-strain curve, and this was confirmed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM). It was found that the particle surface chemistry is a critical factor that dominates the formation of the percolation structure during steady shear. For hydrophobic OTS modified silica filler, this shear-induced reinforcement effect was observed at lower particle loadings than with hydrophilic fumed silica. This relatively stable post-processing structure provides the possibility to achieve improved mechanical reinforcement with low filler loadings.

The influence of extreme shear resulting from ultra-high screw speeds on the bulk polymer and filler suspension showed competing effects of molecular weight degradation and improved filler dispersion on the mechanical and rheological performance of the nanocomposites. While the molecular weight of bulk polymer matrix was significantly reduced, the extreme shear increased the formation of highly percolated clusters of silica particles with bridged polymers, and further led to remarkable reinforcement in the nanocomposites. The degree of reinforcement also depended on the silica surface treatment, with long chain OTS-silica yielding the highest reinforcement. It iwas therefore concluded that processing conditions need to be tailored for specific polymer-particle systems to reach optimum dispersion of nanoparticles with bound polymer layers.

Broader Impacts

The improved particle dispersion achieved through high-speed mixing leads to lighter, stronger and more sustainably manufactured nanocomposites. Knowledge gained on this novel processing technique will inform a range of other multicomponent materials, and is directly applicable to the polymer processing industry. The outreach activities to broaden participation of women in STEM resulted in mentorship networks between engineering students at UMass Lowell and area high school students. Interactions among female faculty and STEM undergraduates were increased through programming developed for the Women in STEM Living-Learning Community. One PhD student, one M.S. student and three undergraduate students produced research papers and presentations and obtained degrees throughout the period of this project.

Modified by: Margaret Sobkowiczkline

Image
  • The low frequency plateau indicates enhanced dispersion, while the lower modulus at high frequency with increasing screw speed indicates reduced molecular weight.
    Journal of Polymer Science PArt B: Polymer Physics

    Margaret Sobkowiczkline
    Nanocomposite Rheology
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This BRIGE project studied high-speed twin screw extrusion processing as a means of improving the thermophysical properties of renewable polymers through formation of nanocomposites. Biobased polyester poly(butylene succinate) (PBS) was compounded with a range of surface-functionalized silicas, and the effects of high shear and interfacial energy on the nanocomposite microstructure, rheology and properties were explored. The outcomes of this work were: (1) increased understanding of the ability of a novel, ultra-high speed extruder to disperse nanoscale particles in a polymer matrix, (2) the effects of that dispersion on rheological properties, and (3) increased participation of women in engineering through cooperative education outreach at high schools. The findings of this research project were published in four peer reviewed publications. Intellectual merit This project increased knowledge on rheology and processing for PBS-silica nanocomposites, and demonstrated the effectiveness of two organo-silane grafted silicas vs. hydroxyl-surface silica in reinforcing the polymer. Knowledge gained on this novel processing technique will inform a range of other multicomponent materials, and is directly applicable to the polymer processing industry. The outreach activities to broaden participation of women in STEM resulted in mentorship networks between engineering students at UMass Lowell and area high school students. Interactions among female faculty and STEM undergraduates were increased through programming developed for the Women in STEM Living-Learning Community. One PhD student, one M.S. student and three undergraduate students produced research papers and presentations and obtained degrees throughout the period of this project.
